{{Infobox person | image = | image_size = 150px | | name = Claes Elefalk | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1959 | birth_place = Stockholm, Sweden | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = [[Stockholm, Sweden]] | nationality = Sweden | other_names = | known_for = Mats Sundin's & Fredrik Ljungberg´s agent | education = | employer = [[Creative Artists Agency]]
[[IMG Artists]] | occupation = [[Sports agent]] | title = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Claes Elefalk''' is a [[Swedish language|Swedish]] [[sports agent]] at the [[Creative Artists Agency]]. == Career == Elefalk is a Swedish Sports agent whose representation include some high-profile athletes. From the early 1990s, Elefalk worked as an agent at [[IMG (company)|IMG]] Sweden until 2006.https://www.theguardian.com/football/2000/feb/23/thefiver.sport He held a Vice Presidential position within the company before moving to the illustrious [[Creative Artists Agency]] and their division CAA Sports. Elefalk works out of Creative Artists's Stockholm location. == Clients == Elefalk's clients are mostly [[ice hockey]] players and [[soccer]] players usually of Swedish extraction. === CAA Sports (Creative Artists Agency) === He represents NHL hockey players [[Mats Sundin]],{{cite web |url=http://press.jrc.it/NewsExplorer/entities/en/689659.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012060227/http://press.jrc.it/NewsExplorer/entities/en/689659.html |archivedate=2008-10-12 |df= }} [[Daniel Alfredsson]], [[Daniel Sedin]], [[Henrik Sedin]], [[Mathias Tjärnqvist]], [[Niklas Kronwall]], [[Staffan Kronwall]], [[Marcus Nilson]], [[Fredrik Sjöström]], [[Loui Eriksson]], [[Oscar Möller]], [[Mattias Öhlund]], [[Ossi Väänänen]], [[Lauri Tukonen]], [[Andreas Jämtin]], [[Kenny Jönsson]], [[Jörgen Jönsson]], [[Niclas Bergfors]], [[Johan Davidsson]], [[Mikael Backlund]], [[Mathias Johansson (ice hockey)|Mathias Johansson]], [[Fabian Brunnström]],{{cite web |url=http://www.hockeyexpressen.se/Nyheter/1.1122516/fabian-brunnstrom-far-dromkontrakt-med-vancouver |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080616094817/http://www.hockeyexpressen.se/Nyheter/1.1122516/fabian-brunnstrom-far-dromkontrakt-med-vancouver |archivedate=2008-06-16 |df= }} [[Carl Söderberg]]http://www.boston.com/sports/hockey/bruins/articles/2008/08/19/bruins_agent_arent_in_synch/ and [[Per Ledin]], .http://www.kuriren.nu/nyheter/artikel.aspx?ArticleId=3797234 Elefalk also currently represents soccer players [[Fredrik Ljungberg]], [[Pontus Farnerud]], [[Nils-Eric Johansson]], [[Joel Riddez]], [[Jon Lundblad]], [[David Quattlebaum]], and [[David Beckham]]. === IMG === While at IMG, Elefalk represented Brazilian soccer player and former FC Inter Milan coach [[Leonardo Araújo|Leonardo]], Australian soccer player [[Marko Viduka]], [[Nils-Eric Johansson]],http://www.aftonbladet.se/sportbladet/fotboll/england/article287351.ab?service=print [[Martin Dahlin]], [[Anders Limpar]], [[Pascal Simpson]], [[Magnus Pehrsson]], [[Mattias Jonson]] and [[Magnus Hedman]].https://www.theguardian.com/football/2001/jun/05/thefiver.sport ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Elefalk, Claes}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Sports agents]] [[Category:Swedish businesspeople]]

{{Infobox company | name = Commercial International Bank (Egypt) S.A.E.
{{lang|ar|(البنك التجاري الدولي (مصر) (ش.م.م}} | logo = Commercial International Bank logo.svg | logo_size = 200px | type = [[S.A. (corporation)|Société Anonyme Égyptienne]] | traded_as = {{EGX|COMI}}
{{lse|CBKD}}
{{OTCQX|CIBEY}}
[[EGX 30 Index|EGX 30 Component]] | location = [[Cairo, Egypt]] | products = [[Financial Services]], [[credit card]]s, [[Retail banking|consumer banking]], [[Commercial bank|corporate banking]], [[investment banking]], [[mortgage loan]]s, [[private banking]] | key_people = {{unbulleted list | Hisham Ezz Al-Arab
([[Chairman]] and [[Managing Director]]) | Hussein Abaza
([[Chief executive officer|CEO]])}} | industry = [[Banking]] and [[Financial Services]] | subsid = {{Collapsible list |CI-Capital
CIBC
CIAM
CIL
Corplease
Falcon }} | homepage = [http://www.cibeg.com/ www.cibeg.com] | foundation = 1975 | num_employees = 5,983 | revenue = {{Increase}} [[Egyptian Pound|E£]] 10.2 billion (2016){{cite web|url=http://annualreport2016.cibeg.com/CIBAnnualReport.pdf|title=ANNUAL REPORT 2016|publisher=CIB Egypt.|date=|accessdate=2017-06-28|format=PDF}} | operating_income = {{Increase}} [[Egyptian Pound|E£]] 9.5 billion (2016) | net_income = {{Increase}} [[Egyptian Pound|E£]] 5.95 billion (2016) | assets = {{Increase}} [[Egyptian Pound|E£]] 263.85 billion (2016) | equity = {{Increase}} [[Egyptian Pound|E£]] 15.33 billion (2016) }} '''Commercial International Bank (Egypt) S.A.E.''' is an [[Egypt]]ian private-sector bank.{{cite news|title=Egyptian bank plans to expand via partners|last=Kasse|first=Mahmoud|date=2006-08-21|publisher=''International Herald Tribune''}}{{cite web |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/COMI:EY |title=COMI:EGX Stock Quote - Commercial International Bank Egypt SAE - Bloomberg|work=bloomberg.com|accessdate=10 August 2012}} The company corporate headquarters are located in [[Cairo, Egypt]]. The bank serves more than 500,000 clients and has more than 6,000 employees.{{cite web |url= http://www.cibeg.com/English/InvestorRelations/Pages/Fast-facts.aspx }} The company is ranked in the Forbes Global 2000{{cite web |url= https://www.forbes.com/companies/commercial-international-bank/}} listing which represents the largest corporations in the world. Currently, there are only two Egyptian companies making the list. == History == Commercial International Bank was established in 1975 as a joint venture between the [[National Bank of Egypt]] (51%) and the Chase Manhattan Bank (49%) under the name "Chase National Bank of Egypt”. Mr. Ali Dabbous was Chase National Bank’s first Chairman, serving from 1975 to 1982.http://annualreport2015.cibeg.com/ Following Chase's decision to divest its equity stake in 1987, National Bank of Egypt (NBE) increased its shareholding to 99.9%, and the Bank changed its name to Commercial International Bank (Egypt) S.A.E. NBE’s stake gradually decreased through several public offerings till it reached 18.7%. In 2006, a Consortium led by Ripplewood Holdings acquired the NBE stake. In July 2009, Actis a leading emerging markets private equity firm, invested US$244 million to acquire shares in CIB. Hence, Actis acquired 50% of the stake held by the Consortium led by Ripplewood Holdings. Five months later, Ripplewood sold its remaining position of 4.7% in CIB through the open market. This move marked the successful transition of strategic partnership to be with Actis, who then became the largest shareholder in CIB with a 9.1% stake. In March 2014, Actis sold a portion of its holding in CIB, representing 2.6% of the Bank’s total outstanding shares, in the open market to a group of international investors. Later in the year, Actis, has successfully released its investment in Commercial International Bank (CIB) and has sold its remaining 6.5% to Subsidiaries wholly owned by Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd (“Fairfax”) in May 2014. ==CI Capital== '''CI Capital''' is the investment banking arm of the Commercial Internationational Bank (CIB) with corporate headquarters in Cairo. It is one of the largest investments banks in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region. In 2015, Global Finance Magazine ranked CI Capital as the best Investment Bank in Egypt.{{cite web |url= https://www.gfmag.com/media/press-releasess/global-finance-names-worlds-best-investment-banks-2015?page=4 }} The investment bank serves a range of clients including governments, corporations, financial institutions, high-net-worth individuals and retail customers. CI Capital has the following four divisions: '''Asset Management'''.{{cite web |url= http://www.noozz.com/Pages/CI-Capital/13 }} CI Capital Asset Management (CIAM) is the largest bank-backed asset manager in Egypt and second-ranked overall with more than EGP 11 billion in Assets under Management. CIAM offers fixed income, money market and equity products. '''Investment Banking'''. CI Capital have advised on transactions worth in excess of EGP 84 billion since inception, including initial public offerings, secondary offerings, private placements, rights issues, debt restructurings and bond issuances. CI Capital Investment Banking is the partner of choice for major national, regional clients seeking sophisticated advisory on complex national and cross-border M&A, equity and debt capital markets, and corporate finance transactions. '''Securities Brokerage'''. CI Securities Brokerage (CIBC) is the number one securities broker in Egypt by market share of trading executions.{{cite web |url= http://www.cibc-dynamic.com.eg/pr-single3.html}} The division was the only broker in Egypt to execute transactions worth in excess of EGP 1 billion last year. '''Research'''. CI Capital Research has a coverage of more than 80% of the aggregate MENA market cap. The department offers an unrivaled, comprehensive product lineup as well as access to senior management at leading MENA corporations via management roadshows, reverse roadshows, and one-on-one conference calls. They are also the organizer of the largest Egypt-focused investor conferences held annually across Cairo, South Africa, London and New York, which play host to participants including high-level Egyptian government officials, Central Bank of Egypt policymakers, and senior corporate managers.{{cite web |url= http://www.newyorkpalace.com/ci-capitals-third-annual-egypt-conference-2015 }} ==CorpLease== CorpLease (Corporate Leasing Company Egypt S.A.E) is a broad-based financial services company operating in Egypt since 2004 and providing a range of leasing products and services.{{cite web |url= http://www.corplease.com.eg/abt.html}} It focuses on large and medium ticket leasing transactions in all sectors and industries. CorpLease has four primary business lines: Vendor Finance, Direct Leasing, SME Finance and Structured Finance. ==Commercial International Insurance (CIL)== Commercial International Life Insurance was formed in 1999 as an Egyptian joint stock company offering international value-for-money life insurance products. As of March 2014, CIB gross loan book reached EGP 46 billion, while customer deposits marked EGP 103 billion, with a paid-in capital of EGP 9 billion. The Bank has the largest market capitalization in the Egyptian Banking sector, amounting to over EGP 33 billion as of March 2014, and operates a wide distribution network of 155 outlets and more than 500 ATMs.{{cite web |url= http://www.cibeg.com/English/AboutCIB/Pages/Awards.aspx}} ==Awards and recognitions== CIB is recognized as the bank with the strongest brand equity in corporate banking in Egypt, it has also been consistently recognized on a global level as the 'Best Bank in Egypt', an award it has received on numerous occasions by publications such as The Banker, Global Finance, Euromoney and Emerging Markets.{{cite web |url= http://middleeastarab.com/eg/dir/commercial-international-bank-cib.html }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.cibeg.com CIB website] [[Category:1975 establishments in Egypt]] [[Category:Banks established in 1975]] [[Category:Banks of Egypt]] [[Category:Companies based in Cairo]] [[Category:Egyptian brands]]

[[File:Winfrith Technology Centre - geograph.org.uk - 1768198.jpg|thumb|right]] '''Dorset Green Technology Park''' (formerly '''Winfrith Technology Centre''') is a science and technology park which is owned by the [[Homes and Communities Agency]]. The site was the former [[UKAEA]] [[Winfrith|Winfrith Atomic Energy Establishment]] which was in service from the 1950s to early 1990s. The [[Steam Generating Heavy Water Reactor]] was also developed at the site.
The centre is situated near the village of [[Winfrith Newburgh]], which is some eight miles west of [[Wareham, Dorset|Wareham]] and nine miles east of Dorchester.
==History== ===Winfrith Technology Centre=== Winfrith Technology Centre dates from the 1980s when part of the [[UKAEA]] site was already being referred to by that name.<ref>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Winfrith Technology Centre |journal=Engineering World |publisher= Society of Engineers Limited |date=1989 |volume=80-83 |page=26 }}</ref> It was used as a research and development centre in support of the nuclear, oil and gas industries.
By the early 21st century, under the ownership of UKAEA, the centre was home to about 50 companies including defence technology company [[QinetiQ]] which operated its underwater technology business there.<ref name="bbc1">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/3669631.stm |title=UK atomic shutdown 30 years early|publisher=BBC News|date=30 April 2004|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="did1">{{cite news |url=http://www.defenseindustrydaily.com/QinetiQ-Sells-Underwater-Systems-Division-to-Atlas-05423/|title=QinetiQ Sells Underwater Systems Division to Atlas|publisher=Defense Industry Daily|date=May 17, 2009|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> QinetiQ would later sell its underwater technology division to [[Atlas Elektronik]] in 2009,<ref name="did1"/> whilst still remaining a tenant at Winfrith.<ref name="de1">{{cite news |url=http://www.dorsetecho.co.uk/news/11755997.26_000_jobs_bonanza_to_follow___12_6_million_government_investment_in_county/?ref=mr|title=26,000 jobs bonanza to follow £12.6 million government investment in county|publisher=Dorset Echo|date=29 January 2015|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref>
In 2004 Winfrith Technology Centre was sold to the UK government's regeneration agency, [[English Partnerships]] for £7.54 million.<ref name="bbc1"/> English Partnerships' ownership passed to its successor body, the [[Homes and Communities Agency]], in December 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.insidehousing.co.uk/story.aspx?storycode=6502107|title=Inside Housing: New agencies will face 'huge challenges|publisher=Inside Housing|date=1 December 2008|accessdate=3 February 2015}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===Dorset Green Technology Park=== In early 2008 English Partnerships appointed Zog Brownfield Ventures to redevelop the Technology Centre.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.building.co.uk/ep-appoints-zog-and-hbos-to-redevelop-atomic-centre/3107119.article|title=EP appoints Zog and HBOS to redevelop atomic centre|publisher=Building.co.u|date=25 February 2008|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> The intention was "to create an eco-friendly business complex".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dorsetecho.co.uk/news/1965511.zerocarbon_plans_at_former_nuclear_site/|title=Zero-carbon plans at former nuclear site|publisher=Dorset Echo|date=15 January 2008|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> By 2009 the site was being called the Dorset Green Technology Park.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dorsetecho.co.uk/news/9092082.Ideas_appeal_for_ex_nuclear_site_in_Winfrith/|title=The Dorset Green Technology Park |publisher=Dorset Echo|date=19 June 2011|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> There are currently major plans to expand and redevelop the site.<ref name="de1"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20141218123127/http://dorsetgreen.co.uk/ Dorset Green Technology Park]
{{coord|50|40|57|N|2|15|56|W|region:GB_type:city|display=title}}
[[Category:Science and technology in Dorset]] [[Category:Science parks in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Business parks of England]]

revision.text:
{{about|a neighbourhood in the city of Thunder Bay, Ontario|the former city that was amalgamated in 1970|Fort William, Ontario}} {| class="infobox" style="font-size:90%;width:250px;text-align:center;line-height:100%;" |- ! colspan="2" style="background:#DDDDDD;line-height:110%;" | Downtown Fort William |- | colspan="2" | [[Image:Scotiabank Fort William.jpg|border|235px]] |- | colspan="2" | Cuthbertson Block built 1908[http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=783 Thunder Bay Street Tours - Cuthburtson Block] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071108014944/http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=783 |date=November 8, 2007 }}
|- | style="border-right:1px solid #AAAAAA;" | '''Population'''
2,000 | '''Ward'''
McKellar and
Westfort wards |- | colspan="2" | {{superimpose |base = Map of Thunder Bay.svg |base_width = 235px |base_caption = Downtown Fort William |float = Red pog.svg |float_width = 9px |float_caption = Thunder Bay, Ontario |x = 135 |y = 145 }} |- | colspan="2" | Location in Thunder Bay |} '''Downtown Fort William''', also known as '''Downtown Thunder Bay South''' or '''the South Core''', is the urban core of the former city of [[Fort William, Ontario|Fort William]], the southern half of [[Thunder Bay]], [[Ontario]]. It is centred on Victoriaville Civic Centre, an indoor [[shopping mall]] and [[civic centre]] built as part of an [[urban renewal]] project in the 1980s.Tronrud, Thorold J; Epp, Ernest A.; and others. (1995). ''[http://www.thunderbaymuseum.com/publications.htm Thunder Bay: From Rivalry to Unity] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207031852/http://www.thunderbaymuseum.com/publications.htm |date=February 7, 2012 }}''. [[Thunder Bay Historical Museum Society]], pp 234. {{ISBN|0-920119-22-0}}. It is separated from the [[Kaministiquia River]] by the [[Canadian Pacific Railway]] line, and its topography is relatively flat. Downtown Fort William is the location of [[Thunder Bay City Hall]], and numerous other government offices. ==History== Downtown Fort William is one of the three nodes around which urban growth began in the Lakehead area. In 1883 the [[Canadian government]] transferred responsibility for the [[Transcontinental railroad#Canada|Transcontinental railway]] to the private [[Canadian Pacific Railway]], which subsequently relocated the Lake Superior terminus from the Fort William Town Plot (West Fort William) to the lower Kaministiquia River, seven kilometres downstream from [[Westfort]]. Growth began at the intersection of Victoria Avenue and Simpson Street, because the McVicar family had negotiated an agreement with the CPR to place the railway station on the McVicar patent, and because the CPR had erected its second and third Thunder Bay grain elevators (CPR Elevators A & B) at the foot of Victoria Avenue in 1884/85 and 1888. In 1891 the Municipality of Neebing acquired land from the McKellar family and began construction of a town hall on Donald Street Fort William Journal 2 & 5 & 26 Sept 1891 which, when Fort William was incorporated in 1892, became the town hall of Fort William.Tronrud, Thorold J; Epp, Ernest A.; and others. (1995). ''[http://www.thunderbaymuseum.com/publications.htm Thunder Bay: From Rivalry to Unity] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207031852/http://www.thunderbaymuseum.com/publications.htm |date=February 7, 2012 }}''. [[Thunder Bay Historical Museum Society]], pp 57. {{ISBN|0-920119-22-0}}. and due to [[Port Arthur, Ontario|Port Arthur]]'s lack of a city hall, became the location of [[Thunder Bay City Hall]] after the [[Amalgamation (politics)|amalgamation]] of the two cities in 1970. ==Demographics== [[Image:Paterson Court Thunder Bay.jpg|thumb|Paterson Court]] The downtown area has a population of approximately 1,000 and a median age of approximately 47 years. The south core has a larger aboriginal population than much of the rest of the city, and the lowest average income in Thunder Bay.[[Statistics Canada]]. Profile of Census Tract 5950006.00, Thunder Bay, Ontario. [[Canada 2006 Census|2006 Census]]. Statistics Canada Catalogue no. 92-597-XWE. Ottawa. Released December 4, 2007. Retrieved March 1, 2008.Income statistics: [http://www.thunderbay.ca/docs/business/1176.pdf Shopping in Thunder Bay] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061007151355/http://www.thunderbay.ca/docs/business/1176.pdf |date=October 7, 2006 }}, pp. 5. Retrieved March 1. 2008. Statistics Canada income data for 2006 will be released on May 1, 2008. The south core is the location of several apartment buildings aimed to low income individuals and seniors. It also has a relatively large homeless contingent and is the location of the [[Homeless shelter|Rotary Shelter House]].[http://www.shelterhouse.on.ca/ Shelter House Thunder Bay]. The [[John Howard Society]], an organization dedicated to assist people who have come into conflict with the law, is located in the old [[YMCA]] building.[http://www.johnhowardtbay.on.ca/ John Howard Society of Thunder Bay]. Crime is recognized to be a problem in the south core, especially near the Brodie Street [[Bus station|bus terminal]]. [[Thunder Bay Police]] operates the McKellar Neighbourhood Policing Office across the street from the bus terminal and has cruisers drive by on a regular basis.[[Thunder Bay Police Service]], [http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=2307 Neighbourhood Policing] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006173127/http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=2307 |date=October 6, 2007 }}. ==Economy== [[Image:Victoria Street Thunder Bay.jpg|thumb|Victoria Avenue East]] Neither of Thunder Bay's downtown cores overshadowed the other, and both are today less important economically than the Intercity area. However, the South Core continues to be an employment centre. Several thousand people work in the core every day. The largest employers in the area include the [[Local government|city government]] of Thunder Bay, the StarTek [[Call centre|Call Centre]], and various businesses in the Victoriaville Civic Centre.[http://www.thunderbay.ca/docs/business/2284.pdf Major Employer List 2007] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070809121416/http://www.thunderbay.ca/docs/business/2284.pdf |date=August 9, 2007 }} The core is home to branches of four of Canada's five major banks, and several [[credit union]]s. Several industrial businesses are located in the neighbourhood, primarily on the eastern side of the neighbourhood, and the Canadian Pacific [[Train station|Train Station]] is located in the southernmost part of the neighbourhood. ==Arts and culture== Downtown Fort William is the location of many [[cultural institutions]]. The [[Thunder Bay Historical Museum]] occupies the renovated Fort William [[police station]] on Donald Street, one of the core's many historical landmarks. It is operated by the century-old Thunder Bay Historical Museum Society and has three floors of galleries, including a [[Prison cell|jail cell]] and recreation of a Fort William street from the early 20th century.[http://www.thunderbaymuseum.com/ Thunder Bay Historical Museum Society] Also located off Donald Street is the Brodie Street Art Gallery, which showcases local artists and offers watercolour lessons by local painter Peter Humeniuk.[http://www.bigbrush.com Big Brush.com], website for the Brodie Street Art Gallery. [[Thunder Bay Public Library|Brodie Resource Library]] is located on Brodie Street beside city hall. It was opened in 1912 as Fort William's Carnegie Library.[http://www.tbpl.ca/internal.asp?id=78&cid=256 History of the Thunder Bay Public Library] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060828223757/http://www.tbpl.ca/internal.asp?id=78&cid=256 |date=August 28, 2006 }} The [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]]'s Thunder Bay studio is located on Miles Street on the former site of St Joseph's Convent. facing the former St Stanislaus school. It is the broadcasting centre for [[CBQ-FM|CBQ]] and [[CBQT-FM|CBQT]]. A [[webcam]] is mounted on top of its broadcasting antenna, and looks out over the Simpson-Ogden neighbourhood. ===Places of worship=== [[Image:St Andrews Presbyterian Church Thunder Bay.jpg|thumb|left|St. Andrews Presbyterian]] Several churches are located in the core, the most prominent being St. Andrews [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterian Church]], located at the corner of Brodie and Donald Streets. A city-designated heritage property, it was designed in 1909 by Stinson and Hood architects in the [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic Revival style]]. It features a covered entrance supported by granite columns with floral capitals, a unique feature in Thunder Bay, and its [[bell tower]] dominates the area's skyline.Blumenson, John J. G. (1990). ''Ontario Architecture: A Guide to Styles and Building Terms (1874–1984)''. Fitzhenry & Whiteside, pp. 46 {{ISBN|0-88902-872-9}}.[http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=streetandrewspresbyterianchurch-thunderbay-canada St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church] at [[Emporis]].com St Patrick's Cathedral, the episcopal seat of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Thunder Bay]], was built in 1963 at the corner of Donald and Archibald streets.[http://www.stpatrickscathedral.ca/ St. Patrick's Cathedral][http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=795 Thunder Bay Walking Tours - St. Patrick's Cathedral] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071108013415/http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=795 |date=November 8, 2007 }} Other prominent churches include St. Paul's [[Anglican Communion|Anglican Church]] at the corner of Ridgeway and Archibald, [[St. Andrew's Church, Thunder Bay|St. Andrew's Church]], and Wesley United Church at the corner of Brodie and Miles streets, across from the Brodie Street bus terminal and Paterson Park.[http://www.stpaulsanglicanchurch.ca/ St. Paul's Anglican Church].[http://www.profilecanada.com/companydetail.cfm?company=531675_Wesley_United_Church_Thunder_Bay_ON Wesley United Church] at Profile Canada ==Sports and recreation== The [[Northwestern Ontario Sports Hall of Fame]] is located in the south core on May Street, beside city hall.[http://www.nwosportshalloffame.com/ Northwestern Ontario Sports Hall of Fame] The [[Fort William Gardens]] is located at the corner of Vickers and Miles streets, and is a 4,700 seat arena.[http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=468 Fort William Gardens website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011153645/http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=468 |date=October 11, 2007 }} ==Parks== There are many parks and parkettes in the south core, the most notable is Paterson Park, located on the former site of the Fort William Central School on May Street between Miles and Leith streets. The park was named after Norman M. Paterson, a [[Senate of Canada|Senator]] and founder of [[Paterson GlobalFoods]]. The park features a fountain and benches on an artificial hill.Tronrud, Thorold J. & Nicholson, David (2005). ''[http://www.thunderbaymuseum.com/publications.htm Thunder Bay Quiz Book: 101 Fascinating Questions about our History] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207031852/http://www.thunderbaymuseum.com/publications.htm |date=February 7, 2012 }}''. [[Thunder Bay Historical Museum Society]], pps. 13 (question) and 42 (answer) {{ISBN|0-920119-50-6}}. Located along the Kaministiquia River is the Kaministiquia River Heritage Park, which features a [[Via Rail]] train display, a restored [[Tugboat]], a boardwalk, and a [[stainless steel]] sculpture titled "Animikie", which is [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] for "[[Thunderbird (mythology)|thunder bird]]".[http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=1925 Kaministiquia River Heritage Park Website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026070819/http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=1925 |date=October 26, 2007 }} ==Education== [[Image:Fort William Collegiate Institute.jpg|thumb|Fort William Collegiate Institute]] Many schools were located in the downtown area, but as the population aged and the number of families decreased, most were closed. The only school operating in the core today is McKellar Park Central School, which has classes from [[Kindergarten]] to grade 8 and was ranked by the [[Frasier Institute]] as the worst in Thunder Bay in 2008."[http://www.tbsource.com/Localnews/index.asp?cid=104890 School boards respond to Fraser Institute ranking]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}", TBSource. (February 19, 2008) Retrieved on 2 March 2008. St. Stanislaus School was a [[Catholic school]] located at the corner of Miles and North streets. It is now an office building.[http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=796 Thunder Bay Walking Tours - Saint Stanislaus School] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071108013709/http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=796 |date=November 8, 2007 }} Fort William Central School (built 1895) was located at the corner of Miles and May streets, and was demolished in the late 1950s for Paterson Park. Fort William [[Collegiate Institute]] was a [[High school|secondary school]] located just south of the core which closed in 2005. Plans are underway to convert the building to residential uses."[http://www.tbsource.com/Localnews/index.asp?cid=103747 Public willing to buy into condo plan proposed for FWCI]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}" TBSource. (January 15, 2008) Retrieved March 2, 2008. A branch of the [[Sylvan Learning|Sylvan Learning Centre]] is located on Victoria Avenue.{{Cite web |url=http://tutoring.sylvanlearning.com/centers/P7C1B3/directions.cfm |title=Sylvan Learning Centre Thunder Bay |access-date=2008-03-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716174632/http://tutoring.sylvanlearning.com/centers/P7C1B3/directions.cfm |archive-date=2011-07-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Infrastructure== [[Image:West Arthur Place Thunder Bay.jpg|thumb|140px|left|The Spence Clinic]] The street layout in Downtown Fort William is based on a grid, which is interrupted at several points by Victoriaville Mall, Paterson Park and the former McKellar General Hospital. [[Thunder Bay Transit]] operates a bus terminal in the core. Routes that use the terminal include 1 Mainline, 2 Crosstown, 3 Memorial, 4 Neebing, 8 James, and 12 East End. During [[Rush hour|peak hours]], bus frequency in the core is every 15 minutes.Thunder Bay Transit [http://www.thunderbay.ca/docs/transit/4030.pdf Route Map] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006001326/http://www.thunderbay.ca/docs/transit/4030.pdf |date=October 6, 2007 }} [map], 2006. Retrieved on 17 June 2007. Medical facilities in the core include St. Joseph's Care Group in Victoriaville Civic Centre,"[http://www.sjcg.net/pdf/2007-11-30_SJHC-Officially-Opens.pdf St. Joseph's Health Centre Finally Opens]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}", St. Joseph's Care Group. (November 30, 2007) Retrieved March 2, 2008. the Ridgeway Clinic,[http://www.profilecanada.com/companydetail.cfm?company=2516128_Ridgeway_Clinic_Thunder_Bay_ON Ridgeway Clinic] at Profile Canada the Fort William Clinic,[http://www.profilecanada.com/companydetail.cfm?company=2515286_Fort_William_Clinic_Thunder_Bay_ON Fort William Clinic] at Profile Canada and the Spence Clinic.[http://www.profilecanada.com/companydetail.cfm?company=119669_Spence_Clinic_Thunder_Bay_ON Spence Clinic] at Profile Canada The [[Mayo Clinic]] has an office in Spence Clinic where local residents can receive information about the Mayo Clinic and schedule appointments.[http://www.mayoclinic.org/english/canadian.html Mayo Clinic - Canadian Contact information] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080101233030/http://www.mayoclinic.org/english/canadian.html |date=January 1, 2008 }} {{clear}} ==Photo gallery== Image:Federal Building May Street Thunder Bay.jpg|[[Government of Canada]] offices at the corner of May and Leith, an example of [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts Classicism]].Blumenson, John J. G. (1990). ''Ontario Architecture: A Guide to Styles and Building Terms (1874–1984)''. Fitzhenry & Whiteside, pp. 129 {{ISBN|0-88902-872-9}}. Constructed in 1913 of limestone, its architectural elements have been reduced to their bare essentials, representing a movement toward modern classicism.[http://www.ontarioarchitecture.com/Beauxarts.htm Ontario Architecture], Beaux Arts. Retrieved on March 1, 2008. Image:Royal Edward Arms Thunder Bay.jpg|Built in 1928 as the [[Royal Edward Hotel]], the eight-storey Royal Edward Arms is the oldest "highrise" in Fort William and was designed by Dorr & Dorr architects of Minneapolis.[http://www.ontarioarchitecture.com/Beauxarts.htm Ontario Architecture], Art Deco. Retrieved on March 1, 2008. The upper reaches of the building is decorated with an Art Deco stylization of Gothic ornamentation.Blumenson, John J. G. (1990). ''Ontario Architecture: A Guide to Styles and Building Terms (1874–1984)''. Fitzhenry & Whiteside, pp. 196 {{ISBN|0-88902-872-9}}. Today the building is used for low income housing,[http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=royaledwardhotel-thunderbay-canada Emporis.com], Royal Edward Arms, Thunder Bay. Retrieved March 1, 2008. but during its heyday hosted many famous individuals, including Her Majesty [[Queen Elizabeth II]].[http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=791 Thunder Bay Street Tours - Royal Edward Arms] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110221049/http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=791 |date=November 10, 2007 }} Image:Independent Living Centre.jpg|Independent Living Resource Centre Thunder Bay at 130 South Brodie Street.[http://www.ilrctbay.com/ Independent Living Resource Centre Thunder Bay]. Retrieved March 1, 2008. ILRC Thunder Bay is located in the core of downtown Fort William. Originally built as a Holiday Inn hotel, today this building houses the ILRC, a [[non-profit organization]] that delivers programs and services to all persons with disabilities and the community, as well as several condominium units. Image:Roy Building Thunder Bay.jpg|The Roy Building, designed for John King by Stinson and Hood architects and built in 1908 on Victoria Avenue, was once a [[Zellers]] department store. It was recently restored in 2015.[http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=790 Thunder Bay Street Tours - Roy Building] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110221201/http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=790 |date=November 10, 2007 }} Image:Thunder Bay Chamber of Commerce.jpg|This building at the corner of Syndicate and Donald streets is home to the Thunder Bay Chamber of Commerce, among other businesses.[http://tb-chamber.on.ca/default.asp?pgid=149 Thunder Bay Chamber of Commerce] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080425202206/http://tb-chamber.on.ca/default.asp?pgid=149 |date=April 25, 2008 }}, Contact page. Retrieved March 1, 2008. Image:Federal Building Syndicate Avenue Thunder Bay.jpg|The [[Canada Revenue Agency]] offices at 130 South Syndicate Avenue, across from the Victoriaville [[parkade]]. Designed by T. W. Fuller and built in 1935 this building served as Fort Williams second post office.[http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=785 Thunder Bay Street Tours - Federal Building] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110221445/http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=785 |date=November 10, 2007 }} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * Tronrud, Thorold J. (1993). ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20120207031852/http://www.thunderbaymuseum.com/publications.htm Guardians of Progress: Boosters and Boosterism in Thunder Bay, 1870–1914]''. [[Thunder Bay Historical Museum Society]], {{ISBN|0-920119-16-6}}. * Tronrud, Thorold J; Epp, Ernest A.; and others. (1995). ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20120207031852/http://www.thunderbaymuseum.com/publications.htm Thunder Bay: From Rivalry to Unity]''. [[Thunder Bay Historical Museum Society]], {{ISBN|0-920119-22-0}}. * Piovesana, Roy. ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20080302061414/http://www.dotb.ca/hopecharity.htm Hope & Charity: An Illustrated History of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Thunder Bay]''. [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Thunder Bay]]. ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071205213933/http://www.thunderbay.ca/index.cfm?fuse=html&pg=5032 Fort William Neighbourhood Renewal Plan] {{coord|48|22|56|N|89|14|46|W|display=title|region:CA-ON}} [[Category:Neighbourhoods in Thunder Bay]] [[Category:Central business districts in Canada|Fort William]]

page.title: EU-Malaysia Chamber of Commerce and Industry

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Business organisations in Malaysia‎ to [[:Category:Business organisations based in Malaysia‎]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2017 April 2]].
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{orphan|date=October 2011}} {{essay-like|date=March 2011}} }}
In May 2003 the '''EU-Malaysia Chamber of Commerce and Industry''' (EUMCCI) emerged from the former European Union Business Council (EUBC). EUMCCI is a public non-profit organisation. The Chamber is financed by projects, events, memberships and corporate partnership. It is an umbrella organisation of all EU chambers of commerce and business councils, whose members are also EUMCCI members, altogether more than 1000 corporations. The aim of EUMCCI is to promote, support and develop EU business interests in [[Malaysia]] as well as facilitate trade, commerce and investments between EU and Malaysia. In order to fulfill its mission, EUMCCI carries out activities that will catalyze and stimulate networking of European companies in Malaysia with the Malaysian business community, business associations, relevant ministries, official representations and other Chambers in Asia. These activities are balanced between social and business activities.
== Mission & Objectives == The mission of the EUMCCI is to promote, support and develop EU business interests in Malaysia as well as facilitate trade, commerce and investments between EU and Malaysia. In order to fulfill its mission, EUMCCI carries out activities that will catalyse and stimulate networking of European companies in Malaysia with the Malaysian business community, business associations, relevant ministries, official representations and other Chambers in Asia. These activities are balanced between social and business activities.
The objectives of the EUMCCI: * To develop and enhance EU position and image in Malaysia * High profile lobbying/dialogue with Institutions, Government * Speed up decisions and actions within the ministries and authorities * Promote and market EU technologies, SMEs products and services in Malaysia * Facilitate the dialogue between the European private sector and Malaysian government
== Publications ==
EUMCCI has a wide range of publications available. These include: * '''e-Bulletin'''- a fortnightly free e-mail newsletter, containing all the latest news from the EU, Malaysia and EUMCCI. * '''EUMCCI Review'''- the Chamber’s quarterly Publication with a circulation of 3,000 in Malaysia, Southeast Asia and Europe. * '''Business Directory'''- EUMCCI's Business Directory is a biennial publication containing the contact details of every direct and indirect member of EUMCCI. * '''Trade Issues & Recommendations'''- Contains relevant issues and recommendations from all EUMCCI Committee industries / sectors addressing the concerns of EUMCCI member companies with regards to the business environment in Malaysia.
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * http://www.eumcci.com/
[[Category:Economy of the European Union]] [[Category:Business organisations based in Malaysia]] [[Category:Economy of Malaysia]] [[Category:Chambers of commerce]] [[Category:Foreign trade of Malaysia]] [[Category:International organisations based in Malaysia]]

([[President (corporate title)|President]] and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]])
Wong Tit-shing
([[Chairman|Co-Chair]])
Maria Livanos Cattaui

[[Alan Hassenfeld|Alan G. Hassenfeld]]
([[Emeritus|Emertitus]] [[Chairman|Chair]]) | founded = 2004, [[New York City]] | website = {{url|ethicaltoyprogram.org}} }} The '''ICTI Ethical Toy Program''' (IETP) is an independent, [[Nonprofit organization|not-for-profit organisation]]{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2017/mar/10/china-toy-factories-migrant-workers-disney-mattel-toysrus |title=Chinese toy factories open summer camp for migrant workers' children|work=Guardian}} established in 2004 to safeguard and improve ethical and sustainability standards in the global [[toy]] industry [[supply chain]].{{cite web|url= http://www.corporateknights.com/channels/supply-chain/tek-savvy-toys-13863329/|title=Tech savvy: toys|work=Corporate Knights}} The ICTI Ethical Toy Program oversees the '''Ethical Toy Program''', the ethical [[manufacturing]] program for the [[toy]] industry.{{cite web|url=http://www.toyassociation.org/TIA/Priorities_Policy/workers/Priorities___Policy/Industry_Priorities/Protecting_Workers.aspx?hkey=99c9067b-209f-4829-bb71-297210a1afef#.VzDp78c5mIU |title=Protecting Workers ICTI CARE Process|work=Toy Industry Association}} The Ethical Toy Program is the most widespread [[International labor standards|labor and social standard]] in the [[toy]] industry.{{cite journal|last1=Lin-Hi|first1=Nick|title=Study on the International Council of Toy Industries (ICTI) CARE Process|journal=University of Mannheim|date=2012|url=http://woek.de/web/cms/upload/pdf/aktion_fair_spielt/publikation/lin-hi_2012_study_on_the_icti_care_process.pdf|accessdate=21 April 2016}} The program is based on the ICTI Code of Business Practices.{{cite journal|last1=Lin-Hi|first1=Nick|title=Study on the International Council of Toy Industries (ICTI) CARE Process|journal=University of Mannheim|date=2012|url=http://woek.de/web/cms/upload/pdf/aktion_fair_spielt/publikation/lin-hi_2012_study_on_the_icti_care_process.pdf|accessdate=9 May 2016}} It is estimated that 70% of global toy sales are covered by the Ethical Toy Program.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/b396bd2c-5fb3-11da-a628-0000779e2340.html#axzz46Npskbm5|title=Seasonal swings pile pressure on to suppliers|work=Financial Times}} == History of the ICTI Ethical Toy Program == Working conditions in Asian [[toy]] [[factory|factories]] in the 1990s were under intense scrutiny, most notably following the [[Kader Toy Factory Fire]] in [[Bangkok]] ([[Thailand]]), considered the worst industrial factory fire in history,{{cite news|last1=Symonds|first1=Peter|title=Thai toy factory fire: 10 years after the world’s worst industrial inferno|url=https://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2003/05/kade-m16.html|accessdate=16 Apr 2015|work=World Socialist Web Site|date=2003-05-16}} and a toy factory fire in [[Shenzhen]] ([[China]]) in 1993{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/11/20/world/fire-ravages-a-doll-factory-in-southern-china-killing-81.html|title=Fire Ravages a Doll Factory In Southern China, Killing 81|date=20 November 1993|work=Reuters|via=The New York Times}} which together caused more than 250 deaths.{{cite book|last1=Pangelinan|first1=M A|title=Lives Lost to the Overseas Toy Industry: A Call for Action; in: Loyola of Los Angeles International and Comparative Law Review, 16(3), S. 735– 761|date=1994|accessdate=21 April 2016}} As a reaction to the tragedy, the Hong Kong Toy Coalition was established and published the "Charter on the Safe Production of Toys"{{cite book|author=Ruth Pearson|author2=Gill Seyfang|author3=Rhys Jenkins|title=Corporate Responsibility and Labour Rights: Codes of Conduct in the Global Economy|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn= 978-1-1365-6890-9|page=94 }} in the mid 1990s. In this charter, the Hong Kong Toy Coalition demanded the improvement of labor, social, and safety standards in Chinese [[toy]] [[factory|factories]]. Following the production of the charter, larger toy brands and retailers started to create their own [[Code of Conduct|Codes of Conduct]]. [[Hasbro]] established its “Global Business Ethics Principles” in 1993, [[Zapf Creation]] a [[code of conduct]] in 1995, [[The Walt Disney Corporation]] its “International Labor Standards” in 1996, [[Mattel]] its “Global Manufacturing Principles” 1997, and [[LEGO]] created a [[code of conduct]] in 1997. It is estimated that there were up to 70 different standards{{cite book | last = Biedermann | first = Reinhard | title = Sozialstandards durch private governance Zwei-Stufen-Kooperation in der globalen Spielzeugbranche | publisher = Nomos | location = Baden-Baden | year = 2007 | isbn = 978-3-8452-0126-9 }} which made it difficult for toy factories to comply with varying standards and created significant amounts of duplication of [[audit]]ing in [[factory|factories]]. Therefore, an industry wide ethical manufacturing standard was called for in the toy industry.{{cite journal|last1=Lin-Hi|first1=Nick|title=Study on the International Council of Toy Industries (ICTI) CARE Process|journal=University of Mannheim|date=2012|url=http://woek.de/web/cms/upload/pdf/aktion_fair_spielt/publikation/lin-hi_2012_study_on_the_icti_care_process.pdf|accessdate=21 April 2016}} The International Council of Toy Industries (ICTI) created the Code of Business Practices in 1995.{{cite book|last1=Likosky|first1=Michael|title=Transnational Legal Processes: Globalisation and Power Disparities|date=2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn= 978-0-4069-4674-4|pages=85–86}} In 2002 at the annual general meeting of ICTI, the member toy industry associations unanimously agreed to launch the ICTI CARE Process, a worldwide [[audit]]ing process to implement the ICTI Code of Business Practices, drive convergence, and reduce duplication of social [[audit]]ing in the global [[toy]] industry [[supply chain]]. In 2004, the ICTI CARE Foundation was created as a [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit organisation]] working completely independently of ICTI to oversee the ICTI CARE Process.{{cite book | last = Byrne | first = Christopher | title = They came to play : 100 years of the Toy Industry Association | publisher = Toy Industry Association | location = United States |pages=77| year = 2016 | isbn = 978-0-692-61707-6 }} In 2018, the organization became the ICTI Ethical Toy Program. Along with a new name, the next generation of the Ethical Toy Program was unveiled with an updated mission and strategy for the organization, a new membership model and a brand-new look and feel to deliver the changes. == Ethical Toy Program Certification Program == Ethical Toy Program is the ethical [[manufacturing]] program specifically designed for the [[toy]] industry based on the ICTI Code of Business Practices.{{cite journal|last1=Lin-Hi|first1=Nick|title=Study on the International Council of Toy Industries (ICTI) CARE Process|journal=University of Mannheim|date=2012|url=http://woek.de/web/cms/upload/pdf/aktion_fair_spielt/publikation/lin-hi_2012_study_on_the_icti_care_process.pdf|accessdate=21 April 2016}} === ICTI Code of Business Practices === The ICTI Code of Business Practices, upon which the Ethical Toy Program is based, covers nine core principals: * [[Working time|Working hours]] must not be excessive & [[overtime]] must be voluntary * Legal and fair pay * No [[child labor]] * No [[Contemporary slavery|forced or involuntary labor]] * No [[discrimination]] * [[Employment|Employees]] must be treated with [[dignity]] and [[respect]] * [[Employment|Employees']] [[Freedom of association|right of association]] must be observed * Individual written labor [[contract]]s must be provided * [[Occupational safety and health|Working conditions are safe]] and [[Employment|employee]] health is not endangered{{cite journal|last1=Lin-Hi|first1=Nick|title=Study on the International Council of Toy Industries (ICTI) CARE Process|journal=University of Mannheim|date=2012|url=http://woek.de/web/cms/upload/pdf/aktion_fair_spielt/publikation/lin-hi_2012_study_on_the_icti_care_process.pdf|accessdate=21 April 2016}} === Certification === When a [[factory]] is awarded a Seal of [[Regulatory compliance|Compliance]] by the Ethical Toy Program this denotes their adherence to the Ethical Toy Program. The Ethical Toy Program offers Seals of Compliance from Class A to C depending on the maximum number of [[working time|hours worked]]. ==See also== *[[Fair trade]] *[[Certification]] *[[Toy Industry Association]] == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Business organisations based in Hong Kong]] [[Category:Business ethics organizations]] [[Category:Toy industry]]

revision.comment: /* Further reading */ Adding link to orphaned article, Wikiproject Orphanage: [[Wikipedia:ORPHAN|You can help!]]
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=December 2015}}
''''A [[management system]] is the framework of processes and procedures used to ensure that an organization can fulfill all tasks required to achieve its objectives.
After World War II, the reigning paradigm of product-oriented mass production had reached its peak. Examples of management systems at that time are [[Assembly lines|linear assembly lines]], organizational hierarchies of command, [[Quality control|product quality control]] and mass consumption.
Soon afterwards, the [[W. Edwards Deming|Deming]]-[[Joseph M. Juran|Juran]] process-quality teachings spearheaded a new quality orientation (later referred to as [[Total quality management]]) and propelled Japan directly to the post-war process focus (process quality control, [[Just in time (business)|just-in-time]], continuous improvement).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2004-08-29/deming-and-juran-the-kings-of-quality | title=Deming And Juran: The Kings Of Quality | publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek | date=August 2004}}</ref> The US responded by a painful and prolonged product-to-process transformation, ultimately leveling the playing field again by the mid 1980s.
At the end of the 1980s, [[business process reengineering]] focused on the radical redesign of the production process through the reintegration of task, labor and knowledge. As a result, lean, flexible and streamlined production processes were created, capable of fast response and internet-based integration necessary for the upcoming phase of supply chains - [[business-to-business]] (B2B) – as well as demand chains – [[Consumer-to-business|business-to-customer]] (B2C).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bmmagazine.co.uk/in-business/advice/18436/the-evolution-of-management/ | title=The Evolution of Management | publisher=Business Matters | year=May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.strategicleadershipinstitute.net/news/the-historical-evolution-of-management-theory-from-1900-to-present-the-changing-role-of-leaders-in-organizations-/ | title=The Historical Evolution of Management Theory from 1900 to Present: The Changing role of Leaders in Organizations | publisher=Strategic Leadership Institute | last=Bosman | first=Manie | year=January 2009}}</ref>
In the above three stages of '''Evolution of Management Systems''', the competitive advantage was derived almost exclusively from the internal resources of the firm. At the end of the 1980s, a radical fourth shift has occurred: the competitive advantage became increasingly derived from the external resources of the firm – through the extended networks of suppliers and customers.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://eds.a.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=4&sid=f425a546-b334-4aff-a38e-a48ccc251d39%40sessionmgr4005&hid=4108 | title=THE EVOLUTION OF MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS | date=March 1970 | last=Ackoff | first=Russell L. | journal=CORS Journal | volume=8 | issue=1 | page=P 1–13 | issn=0574-9638}}</ref>
[[File:Figure 1 Basic scheme product, process, external networks.PNG|thumb|'''Figure 1 Basic scheme: product, process, external networks'''|533x533px]] Figure 1 refers to the basic scheme of production and service delivery process. It represents the traditional linear input-process-output management system. This system has been fixed and unchanging for centuries. The only change has been in terms of changing focus on individual components of the system, emphasizing different parts of this basic scheme.
Although the scheme itself (inputs → process → outputs) remains mostly unchallenged, there are some indications that this business model will undergo major restructurings in the future (in the emerging stages of Evolution of Management Systems). It will become disaggregated and distributed, subjected to non-linear modularity<ref>{{cite journal|last=Slotine|first=Jean-Jacques|title=Modular Stability Tools for Distributed Computation and Control|journal=International Journal of Adaptive Control and Signal Processing|volume=17|url=http://web.mit.edu/nsl/www/preprints/modular.pdf}}</ref> and bringing forth new ways of making things and delivering services. Then it will become reintegrated again, tying together globally distributed components into a unified recycling whole.
== Early stages == All early stages are characterized by changing focus of attention within the unchanging, invariant scheme of Figure 1. The management system has typically focused on:
=== Final product ===
The final product is a primary focus, the production process is considered secondary. Its operations and their sequences are technologically fixed or ‘given’. Product quality is ‘inspected in’, mostly at the end of the process. [[Statistical quality control]], [[inventory control]], cost minimization, mass production, [[assembly line]], work specialization, hierarchies of command, mass consumption, statistical mass markets and forecasting are among the defining characteristics of this stage.
=== Partitioned process === It is the high-quality process that assures the high-quality product. The main focus was on improving of process operations. Quality of the process was understood as the quality of its operations. Powerful new concepts of [[Total Quality Management]] (TQM), [[Continuous Improvement Process]] ([[Kaizen]]) and Just-In-Time (JIT) systems have characterized this stage. Although the operations were being improved, the process architecture and structural sequencing were kept intact and remained technologically ‘given’.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.springer.com/978-3-642-36683-3 | title=The Evolution of the Concept of‘Management Control’ | publisher=Springer | year=2004}}</ref>
=== Integrated process === The focus of attention shifted from operations (circles) to linkages (arrows) – thus changing the process architecture itself. The reengineering of the process, re-integrating individual components into effective, more autonomous and even self-manageable wholes, has characterized this stage.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ansoff|first=H. Igor|title=Conceptual underpinnings of systematic strategic management|journal=European Journal of Operational Research|date=January 1985|volume=19|issue=1|page=P 2–19|issn=0377-2217|doi=10.1016/0377-2217(85)90303-0}}</ref> The production process became a business process and therefore subject to qualitative redesign and reengineering ([[Business process reengineering|BPR]]). Discontinuous improvement and process innovation replaced the piecemeal continuous improvement. Traditional vertical hierarchies of command have flattened out into more horizontal, process-oriented networks. [[Mass customization]], disintermediation, [[knowledge management]] and autonomous teams have started emerging.
== Extended process == [[File:Extended process and Customer Intervention Point.PNG|thumb|'''Figure 2 Extended process and Customer Intervention Point'''|463x463px]] Figure 2 refers to the paradigmatic shift from internal processes expanded into the extended process – including supplier networks and alliances as well as customer self-service, [[mass customization]] and disintermediation – as the increasingly external sources of competitive advantage.
In this recently peaked stage, networks of suppliers and communities of customers have extended the internal process into a functional and competitive whole. Both internal and external sources of knowledge and competitiveness have formed new core competencies. Supply and demand chains management have emerged, in dependence on shifting CIP (Customer Intervention Point). [[Intranets]] and [[extranets]] have provided a communication medium for B2B and B2C exchanges. Quality has become bundled together with cost, speed and reliability..
Today, powerful processes of [[global sourcing]] bring forth and foster a new set of relationships with customers and suppliers. The firm starts disaggregating its production processes, transferring, leasing or selling selected pieces off to a higher-added value operator or coordinator. Any firm can be only as good as is the network of which it is a part. Consequently, the firm has disaggregated and became a network.
== Distributed process == This emerging stage represents the most radical business refocusing so far. Through the [[global sourcing]], sections and components of the internal process are being outsourced to external providers and contractors in search of the highest added value contribution. Long-term alliances are formed and companies are transforming themselves into networks. Network cooperation is replacing corporate competition: ''[[coopetition]]'' emerges. The majority of companies (also the educational and training institutions) could still be the leading global players in this incessant and accelerating paradigm shifting. Globally distributed process ushers in new forms of organization, coordination and modular integration.
[[File:Distributed process and Outsourcing.PNG|thumb|'''Figure 3 Distributed process and Outsourcing'''|466x466px]] Different parts of the extended process are geographically distributed and often spatially remote. In Figure 3, this distribution is represented by sections OS of the process which have been outsourced to higher added-value providers.<ref>{{cite journal|last=O'Connor|first=Gina Colarelli|title=Organizing for Radical Innovation: An Exploratory Study of the Structural Aspects of RI Management Systems in Large Established Firms|journal=Journal of Product Innovation Management|date=November 2006|volume=23|issue=6|page=P 475–497|url=http://eds.a.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=f425a546-b334-4aff-a38e-a48ccc251d39%40sessionmgr4005&vid=5&hid=4108|issn=0737-6782|doi=10.1111/j.1540-5885.2006.00219.x}}</ref>
Although the Stage 5 (Figure 3) represents the most radical business refocusing emerging so far, still rapidly emerging kernels of the next stage (Figure 4) is taking shape. The evolutionary process, driven by relentless global search for maximum added value, is clearly accelerating. Management systems paradigm or business model, after a century of relative invariance, is becoming a new dynamic source of competitive advantage. Radically distributed supply and demand chains of Stage 5 will clearly have to be coordinated and reintegrated on a global scale. Reintegration processes are proceeding under increasing environmental pressures. The search for added value, after exploring traditional global resources, is now turning towards reuse, recycling, recovery and remanufacturing as new sources of maximizing added value. Innovation in business models will become a norm.
== Recycled process == [[File:Recycled Process and Global Sourcing.PNG|thumb|'''Figure 4 Recycled Process and Global Sourcing'''|465x465px]] During the process of utilizing added value, the asset-recovery practices expand quickly to a majority of products and services (Dell, IBM, Xerox). New products are being designed for extended life spans and multiple profit cycles. Reverse logistics and [[Reverse logistics|reverse logistics management]] (RLM) are adding new loops to the traditionally unidirectional processes of supply chains.<ref>{{cite web|title=Two Steps Forward, One Step Back...|url=http://www.infosys.com/industries/retail/white-papers/Documents/reverse-logistics-management.pdf|publisher=Infosys|author=Saty Chawla}}</ref> Old supply chains have become demand chains and now reverse value chains, demonstrating that value can be added in both directions: through the forward pass of production as well as through the backward pass of recovery and remanufacture. Concepts of easy disassembly, durability, reuse and recycling are built in into equipment design.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Glassey|first=Olivier|title=Exploring the weak signals of starts-ups as a folksonomic system|journal=Technology Analysis & Strategic Management|date=April 2009|volume=21|issue=3|page=P 321–332|doi=10.1080/09537320902750632|issn=0953-7325}}</ref>
Figure 4 refers to closed-loop management system and it represents the Stage 6 of the '''Evolution of Management Systems'''. The new loops in the figure are not just traditional information feedback loops, but real business processes of collection, disassembly, reprocessing and reassembly activities (operations).<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://hbr.org/product/double-loop-management-making-strategy-a-continuous-process/an/B0007A-PDF-ENG | title=Double-Loop Management: Making Strategy a Continuous Process | last=Kaplan | first=Robert | journal=Harvard Business Review | year=July 2000}}</ref> The conventional open-ended linear processes are being redesigned towards closure.
New loops of recycled products and materials, [[energy recovery]] and knowledge renewal are being created within [[Global Sourcing and Supply (GSS)|global-sourcing]] (GS) networks. Product reuse/remanufacture relies on a high residual value which gives a good head start for added value maximization. The system becomes organizationally closed and potentially long-term sustainable or even trans-generations self-sustainable.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mckinsey.com/insights/high_tech_telecoms_internet/the_great_transformer | title=The great transformer: The impact of the Internet on economic growth and prosperity | publisher=McKinsey Global Institute | last=Roxburgh | first=Charles | year=October 2011}}</ref> The "openness" and customization of the product design, upgradeable products, flexible product platforms, mutability and waste-free strategies are being implemented.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sas.com/content/dam/SAS/en_us/doc/whitepaper2/emerging-green-intelligence-104141.pdf | title=Business Analytics and Corporate Sustainability | publisher=BusinessWeek Research Services | year=2009 | page=10}}</ref> However, in this latest stage, new employee skills and managerial knowledge, as well as essential mass customization mindset are yet to be produced, maintained and renewed. Eliminating non-value added resources is still necessary. Integrating production system elements and work functions still needs time to evolve.
== Evolutionary spiral == [[File:The evolutionary spiral of Six Management Systems (SMS).PNG|'''Figure 5 The evolutionary spiral of Six Management Systems (SMS)'''|368x368px]]
Evolutionary spiral of the six management systems (SMS) are indicated in Figure 5.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sei.cmu.edu/reports/01sr005.pdf | title=Spiral Development and Evolutionary Acquisition | publisher=Carnegie Mellon Software Engineering Institute | author=W. J. Hansen}}</ref>
It is appropriate to notice that six-management-system evolution is progressing in an accelerated fashion, the periods of stasis are getting shorter and revolutions are occurring faster. Individual management systems are beginning to overlap and their boundaries are getting blurred. An era of continuous change in business models and management systems emerges: the search for competitive advantage (one over the other) becomes relentless, strenuous and resources depleting. Cooperation networks have to merge into larger entities, reducing competition and expanding collaboration. The search for collaborative advantage (for both jointly) will become the new mode of economic behavior.
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == * Zeleny, Milan (2006) "Innovation Factory: Production of Value-Added Quality and Innovation," ''Economics and Management'', 9, 4, pp. 58–65. * Zeleny, Milan (2007) "The mobile society: effects of global sourcing and network organization"’, ''Int. J. Mobile Learning and Organization'', Vol. 1, No. 1, pp. 30–40. * "Knowledge of Enterprise: Knowledge Management or Knowledge Technology?" ''[[International Journal of Information Technology & Decision Making]]'',1(2002)2, pp. 181–207. * "Entering the Era of Networks: Global Supply and Demand Outsourcing Networks and Alliances," in: ''Quantitative Methoden der Logistik und des Supply Chain Management'', edited by M. Jacquemin, R. Pibornik, and E. Sucky, Verlag Dr. Kovač, Hamburg, 2006, pp. 85–97. * "The mobile society: effects of global sourcing and network organization"’, ''Int. J. Mobile Learning and Organization'', Vol. 1, No. 1, 2007, pp. 30–40. * "Strategy and strategic action in the global era: overcoming the knowing-doing Gap", ''Int. J. Technology Management'', Vol. 43, Nos. 1-3, 2008, pp. 64–75.
[[Category:Management systems]]

revision.text:
'''Farmitalia''' was an Italian pharmaceutical company best known for its parallel discovery with [[Rhone-Poulenc]] of [[daunorubicin]] and subsequent discovery of [[doxorubicin]].<ref name="weiss">{{cite journal |author=Weiss RB |title=The anthracyclines: will we ever find a better doxorubicin? |journal=Seminars in Oncology |volume=19 |issue=6 |pages=670–86 |date=December 1992 |pmid=1462166}}</ref> Farmitalia had been founded in 1935 as a joint venture by [[Rhone-Poulenc]] and [[Montecatini (company)|Montecatini]].<ref name= Lombardia/>
In 1978 it was merged with '''Carlo Erba SpA''', a pharmaceutical company that had been founded in 1853 by the pharmacist Carlo Erba, in which Montecatini had acquired a controlling interest in 1971; the merged company was called Farmitalia Carlo Erba SpA.<ref name="Lombardia">{{cite web |last=Bilotto |first=Antonella |publisher=LombardiaBeniCulturali |url=http://www.lombardiabeniculturali.it/archivi/soggetti-produttori/ente/MIDB0017BE/ |title=Carlo Erba SpA |accessdate=9 May 2017}}</ref>
Farmitalia Carlo Erba was acquired by [[Pharmacia]] in 1993<ref>Staff. [http://annonc.oxfordjournals.org/content/4/5/345.2.extract News: Farmitalia bought by Kabi Pharmacia]. Ann Oncol (1993) 4 (5): 345.</ref> and Pharmacia was acquired by [[Pfizer]] in 2003.<ref>Staff, CNN/Money. April 16, 2003 [http://money.cnn.com/2003/04/16/news/companies/pfizer_pharma/ It's official: Pfizer buys Pharmacia ]</ref>
Drugs discovered at Farmitalia that reached the market included (with date of first publication): * 1960 [[Sulfalene]]<ref>Baruffa G. Clinical trials in Plasmodium falciparum malaria with a long-acting sulphonamide. Trans R Soc Trop Med Hyg. 1966;60(2):222-4. {{PMID|5332105}} </ref><ref>Per prior citation, the first publication: Camerino B, Palamidessi G (1960) Derivati della parazina II. Sulfonamdopir (in Italian). Gazz Chim Ital 90:1802–1815</ref> * 1963 [[Daunorubicin]]<ref>Suarato A, Angelucci F, Geroni C. Ring-B modified anthracyclines. Curr Pharm Des. 1999 Mar;5(3):217-27. Review. {{PMID|10066891}}</ref><ref>Grein A, et al. Descrizione e classificazione di un attinomicete (Streptonryces peucetius sp. nova) produttore di una sostanza ad attivita antitumorale. Giorn. Microbiol. 11: 109~ 118, 1963 </ref> * 1969 [[Doxorubicin]]<ref name="weiss"/><ref name="pmid5365804">{{cite journal |vauthors=Arcamone F, Cassinelli G, Fantini G, etal |title=Adriamycin, 14-hydroxydaunomycin, a new antitumor antibiotic from ''S. peucetius'' var. ''caesius'' |journal=Biotechnol Bioeng |volume=11 |issue=6 |pages=1101–10 |year=1969 |pmid=5365804 |doi=10.1002/bit.260110607}}</ref> * 1980 [[Cabergoline]]<ref name=SuppProtec>[https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/444169/o13295.pdf Council regulation (EEC) no 1768/92 in the matter of Application No SPC/GB94/012 for a Supplementary Protection Certificate in the name of Farmitalia Carlo Erba S. r. l.]</ref><ref>[http://worldwide.espacenet.com/searchResults?submitted=true&&DB=EPODOC&ST=advanced&TI=&AB=&PN=GB%202074566 Espace record: GB 202074566]</ref> * 1984 [[Reboxetine]]<ref>Cocchiara G, et al Comparison of the disposition and of the metabolic pattern of Reboxetine, a new antidepressant, in the rat, dog, monkey and man. Eur J Drug Metab Pharmacokinet. 1991 Jul-Sep;16(3):231-9. {{PMID|1814741}}</ref><ref>First publication per prior citation: Melloni M et al. Potential antidepressant agents. α-aryloxy-benzyl derivatives of ethanolamine and morpholine. Eur J Med Chem, 3 (1984), pp. 235–242</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.farmitalia.net/en/ Farmitalia web site]
==References== {{reflist}}

([[US$]] 3.37 million) | religion = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Félix María Vásquez Espinal''' (born 5 April 1943) is a businessman, philanthropist, and politician from the [[Dominican Republic]]. He is [[Senator]] for the [[Provinces of the Dominican Republic|province]] of [[Sánchez Ramírez Province|Sánchez Ramírez]], elected in 2006, and re-elected in 2010 with 55.14% of the votes.{{cite web|title=Boletines Elecciones Congresuales y Municipales 2010|url=http://www.jce.gov.do/ELECCIONES2010/BOLETINES.aspx|publisher=Junta Central Electoral|accessdate=23 August 2014|language=Spanish|at=At Sánchez Ramírez}} Vásquez was born into a poor family. He and a brother won a scholarship that allowed them to study in a college. He graduated with a [[Masters degree]] in Farming and joined the [[Dominican Air Force]] in the Early 1960s. In 1964 he moved to [[Cotuí]], Sánchez Ramírez, to work in the branch of the state-owned [[Banco Agrícola|Agricultural Bank]], five years later, he started a private business. In 1995, he founded the ''Fundación Félix Vásquez'' [[foundation (nonprofit)|foundation]]. He has been Secretary of State-Advisor and Deputy.{{cite web|title=Senador de la República por la Provincia Sánchez Ramírez, PRSC. |url=http://www.senado.gob.do/senado/OAI/Senadores/F%C3%A9lixV%C3%A1squez.aspx |accessdate=23 August 2014 |language=Spanish |publisher=Senate of the Dominican Republic}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vasquez, Felix}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:People from Dajabón Province]] [[Category:Dominican Republic businesspeople]] [[Category:Social Christian Reformist Party politicians]] [[Category:Dominican Liberation Party politicians]] [[Category:Dominican Republic philanthropists]] [[Category:Dominican Republic military personnel]] [[Category:Members of the Senate of the Dominican Republic]] {{DominicanRepublic-politician-stub}}

{{Infobox person | name = Giancarlo Iliprandi | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth-date|15 March 1925}} | birth_place =[[Milan]], Italy | birth_name = | death_date = {{Death-date and age|16 September 2016|15 March 1925}} | death_place = Milan, Italy | occupation = Graphic designer }} '''Giancarlo Iliprandi''' (15 March 1925 – 16 September 2016) was an Italian graphic designer.
==Early years== Born in [[Milan]], in 1949 Iliprandi graduated in painting and in 1953 in scenography from the [[Brera Academy]]. He was a self-taught graphic designer, inspired by Antonio Boggeri, [[Max Huber (graphic designer)|Max Huber]], Albe Steiner and [[Bruno Munari]].<ref name="auto">Daniele Baroni, Maurizio Vitta. ''Storia del design grafico''. Milano, Longanesi, 2003. {{ISBN|978-88-304-2011-3}}.</ref> In the early 1950s he was able to get commissions from important companies including [[RAI]], [[Honeywell]], [[Hoffmann-La Roche|Roche]], [[La Rinascente]], [[FIAT]], [[Standa]] and Electa.<ref name="auto1">Giorgio Fioravanti. ''Il dizionario del grafico''. Bologna, Zanichelli, 1993. {{ISBN|88-08-14116-0}}.</ref><ref name="corrie">{{cite news|last1=Stefano Bucci|title=Morto Giancarlo Iliprandi, talento di una stagione unica|url=http://www.corriere.it/cultura/16_settembre_16/morto-giancarlo-iliprandi-design-arte-9fa42cca-7bf7-11e6-a2aa-53284309e943.shtml|accessdate=17 September 2016|work=[[Corriere della Sera]]|date=16 September 2016}}</ref>
== Career == Starting from the 1960s, Iliprandi worked as art director for numerous magazines including ''Popular Photography Italiana'', ''Phototeca'', ''Sci nautico'' and ''Interni''. He drew the covers for the records of the label {{Interlanguage link multi|I Dischi del Sole|it}}, and cured the [[corporate identity]] for the companies Cucine RB, Ankerfarm and Stilnovo.<ref name="auto1"/>
During his career he received several awards including: the Grand Prize at the XIII [[Triennale]] (1964);<ref name="auto"/> a prize at the first International Poster Biennale in Warsaw (1966);<ref name="auto"/> and four [[Compasso d'Oro]]. The Compasso d'Oro were in 1979 for the [[font]] Modulo and for the instrumental graphic of the [[Fiat 131 Mirafiori]], in 2004 for the cover design of the magazine ''Arca'' and in 2011 as a career award.<ref name="corrie"/> In 2015 he released an autobiography, ''Note''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Giulio Passerini|title=Note, la biografia di Giancarlo Iliprandi|url=http://www.panorama.it/cultura/libri/note-la-biografia-di-giancarlo-iliprandi/|accessdate=17 September 2016|work=[[Panorama (magazine)|Panorama]]|date=7 September 2015}}</ref>
== Further reading ==
* Giorgio Fioravanti, Leonardo Passarelli, Silvia Sfligiotti. ''La Grafica in Italia''. Milano, Leonardo Arte, 1997. pp. 130-131. {{ISBN|978-88-781-3591-8}}. * Andrea Rauch. "Giancarlo Iliprandi. Impegno, disimpegno". ''Il mondo come Design e Rappresentazione''. Firenze, Usher Arte, 2009. {{ISBN|978-88-950-6537-3}}.

{{Infobox scientist |name = Gustaf de Laval |image = Gustaf de Laval 1875.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = Gustaf de Laval 1875 |birth_date = 9 May 1845 |birth_place = [[Orsa Municipality|Orsa]], [[Dalarna]] |death_date = 2 February 1913 (aged 67) |death_place = [[Stockholm]] |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = [[Sweden|Swedish]] |ethnicity = |field = |work_institutions = |alma_mater = [[Royal Institute of Technology|Institute of Technology in Stockholm]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[Steam turbine]]s, [[dairy]] machinery, and the [[de Laval nozzle]] for rocket engines |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |signature = Gustaf de Laval signature.svg }} '''Karl Gustaf Patrik de Laval''' ({{IPA-sv|²ɡɵsːtav dɛ laˈvalː|-|Sv-Gustaf_de_Laval.ogg}}; 9 May 1845 – 2 February 1913) was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] engineer and inventor who made important contributions to the design of [[steam turbine]]s and [[dairy]] machinery.
==Life== [[File:Gustaf de Lavals smedja.jpg|thumb|left|upright|de Laval's forge in Kloster]] Gustaf de Laval was born at [[Orsa Municipality|Orsa]] in [[Dalarna]] in the Swedish de Laval [[Huguenot]] family (immigrated 1622 - Claude de Laval, soldier - knighted de Laval 1647). He enrolled at the [[Royal Institute of Technology|Institute of Technology in Stockholm]] (later the Royal Institute of Technology, KTH) in 1863, receiving a degree in mechanical engineering in 1866, after which he matriculated at [[Uppsala University]] in 1867.
He was then employed by the Swedish mining company, [[Stora Enso|Stora Kopparberg]]. From there he returned to Uppsala University and completed his doctorate in 1872. He was further employed in [[Kloster, Sweden|Kloster Iron works]] in Husby parish, Sweden.<ref name="Modern compressible flow">Anderson.J.D, Modern compressible flow, Mcgraw Hills, third edition.</ref>
Gustaf de Laval was a member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] from 1886. He was a successful engineer and businessman. He also held national office, being elected to Swedish parliament, from 1888 to 1890 and later became a member of the senate. De Laval died in Stockholm in 1913 at the age of 67.<ref name="Modern compressible flow"/>
== {{anchor|contributions}}Contributions ==
=== [[de Laval nozzle]]=== In 1882 he introduced his concept of an impulse steam turbine<ref name=smil>{{cite book|page= 62| title=Creating the Twentieth Century: Technical Innovations of 1867-1914 and Their Lasting Impact|author= Vaclav Smil|isbn= 0-19-516874-7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w3Mh7qQRM-IC&pg=PA71&lpg=PA71&dq=Transformer+coltman+1988&ct=result#PPA64,M1|accessdate=2009-01-03|year=2005|publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref> and in 1887 built a small steam turbine to demonstrate that such devices could be constructed on that scale. In 1890 Laval developed a [[nozzle]] to increase the steam jet to supersonic speed, working from the kinetic energy of the steam, rather than its pressure. The nozzle, now known as a [[de Laval nozzle]], is used in modern [[rocket engine nozzle]]s. De Laval turbines can run at up to 30,000 rpm. The turbine wheel was mounted on a long flexible shaft, its two bearings spaced far apart on either side. The higher speed of the turbine demanded that he also design new approaches to reduction gearing, which are still in use today. Since the materials available at the time were not strong enough for the immense centrifugal forces, the output from the turbine was limited, and large scale electric steam generators were dominated by designs using the alternative compound steam turbine approach of [[Charles Algernon Parsons|Charles Parsons]].<ref name=smil/>
Using high pressure steam in a turbine that had oil-fed bearings meant that some of the steam contaminated the lube-oil, and as a result, perfecting commercial steam-turbines required that he also develop an effective oil/water separator. After trying several methods, he concluded that a centrifugal separator was the most affordable and effective method. He developed several types, and their success established the centrifugal separator as a useful device in a variety of applications.
=== De Laval cream separators and Alfa Laval === De Laval also made important contributions to the dairy industry, including the first centrifugal [[milk]]-[[cream]] [[cream separator|separator]] and early [[milking machine]]s, the first of which he patented in 1894. It was not until after his death, however, that the company he founded marketed the first commercially practical milking machine, in 1918. Together with Oscar Lamm, de Laval founded the company [[Alfa Laval]] in 1883, which was known as ''AB Separator'' until 1963 when the present name was introduced.
=== DeLaval === In 1991, Alfa Laval Agri, a company producing dairy and farming machinery was split from Alfa Laval when it was bought by the [[Tetra Pak]] Group. When Alfa Laval was sold, Alfa Laval Agri remained a part of the Tetra Pak group and was renamed [[DeLaval]], after the company's founder.
==Image gallery Gustaf de Laval== <gallery widths=200px heights=160px> File:GustafDeLaval.jpg|Gustaf de Laval at the age around 50. File:Impulse Turbine.jpg|Impulse Turbine by Gustaf de Laval. Built in Sweden, 1888. Deutsches Museum, Munich. File:De Leval boat.jpg|A unique submarine invented by Gustaf de Laval<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=QA8AAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22Leval%22&lr=&num=100&as_brr=1&pg=RA4-PA852]</ref> File:De Lavals ångturbinfabrik Järla Nacka 2005-07-31.jpg|The former De Laval steam turbine factory in [[Nacka]] outside Stockholm, now converted to a conference centre. </gallery>
He is interred at [[Norra begravningsplatsen]] in Stockholm, Sweden.
